intro: Bystropogon andinus, commonly known as the Andean mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and gelatinous berries. The plant attaches itself to the branches of host trees, such as oaks and pines, through its haustellum, which penetrates the host's vascular system. Bystropogon andinus plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat by influencing host tree growth and providing food for various bird species. Its unique adaptations allow it to thrive in the challenging environmental conditions of the Andean cloud forests.
